Award.AwardTitle: RIG: Kinetic Characterization of F420 Dependent Glucose- 6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase from M. tuberculosis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
F420 Cofactor Dependent Glucose-6-phosphate Dehydrogenase (FGD) catalyzes the conversion of Glucose-6-phosphate to 6-phosphogluconolactone. The enzymology of F420 dependent enzymes, such as FGD, has not yet been subject to rigorous investigation. The overall goal of this research is to understand the function and hydride transfer reactivity of FGD from Mycobacterium tuberculosis using site-directed mutagenesis, kinetic isotope effects (KIEs), steady-state and pre-steady state methods.

Broader Impacts: This project will support the training of minority students in biochemistry. This work will also enhance the quality of education for participating students because they will acquire essential biochemical skills in the field of enzymology. As an African-American female, the PI is aware of the scarcity of under-represented groups in the scientific community and would like to provide mentoring opportunities to all students interested, including those from under-represented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
FGD:

FGD Purification:  We have over expressed FGD in Mycbacteria smegmatis, with a yield of 10 mg/L (Specific Aim 1). 

We have created FGD H40A variant (specific aim 3), which was inactive, however it was able to bind both substrate can cofactor. The Kd value for F420  and G6P binding for wtFGD were 8.7 ± 0.7 nM and 16.7 ± 4.0 μM, respectively.  However, the Kd value for F420  and G6P binding for FGD H40A variant were 119 ± 26 nM and 9.8 ± 0.9 μM, respectively.  This suggests that the H40 residue does not aid in G6P binding since the wtFGD and FGD H40A binding affinity for G6P are approximately equal within error. However, the data suggests that the H40 residue helps to anchor the F420 Cofactor into the active site.  Importantly, our structure provides the first experimental insight into the nature of G6P substrate binding. 

We (in collaboration with (Dr. Yan (Jessie) Zhang at UT-Austin and Dr. Edward N. Baker from University of Aukland) have solved the crystal structure of the FGD H40A variant in complex with the substrate, G6P to a resolution of 2.9 Å. Our goal is to continue to optimize the crystallization conditions in order to get a higher resolution structure to better understand FGD interactions with G6P. 

Steady State Anaylsis:

FGD activity was assayed by observing the decrease in the absorbance of the oxidized F420 Cofactor at 420 nm upon reduction, using a Cary-100 Spectrophotometer. The reaction kinetics was observed to follow a Michaelis-Menten model (equation 1). See table 1.

               k = kcat[G6P]/(Km+[G6P])                     Equation 1

               Table 1  Steady state kinetic parameters for wtFGD and FGD H40A 

 

Km G6P (μM)

kcat (sec-1)

kcat/Km (M-1sec-1)

wtFGD

21.6 ± 1.5

1.4 ± 0.03

64815

FGD H40A

27.0 ± 4.8

0.0016 ± 0.0001

59.3

 

FNO:

F420H2:NADP+oxidoreductase (Fno), is a separate F420 dependent enzyme found in sulfate reducing archaea and methanogens and thus linked to methane production.  Fno catalyzes the reduction of NADP to NADPH.  With this parallel project, we have: 

Successfully Purified Fno: The Fno gene from Archaeoglobus fulgidus was synthesized in-vitro and cloned into pET24b plasmid by Genescript. The plasmid was transformed into C41(DE3) E. coli A detailed purification procedure has been published in Protein J.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: FGD: FGD Purification: We have over expressed FGD in Mycbacteria smegmatis, with a yield of 10 mg/L (Specific Aim 1). We have created FGD H40A variant (specific aim 3), which was inactive, however it was able to bind both substrate can cofactor. The Kd value for F420 and G6P binding for wtFGD were 8.7 ± 0.7 nM and 16.7 ± 4.0 μM, respectively. However, the Kd value for F420 and G6P binding for FGD H40A variant were 119 ± 26 nM and 9.8 ± 0.9 μM, respectively. This suggests that the H40 residue does not aid in G6P binding since the wtFGD and FGD H40A binding affinity for G6P are approximately equal within error. However, the data suggests that the H40 residue helps to anchor the F420 Cofactor into the active site. Importantly, our structure provides the first experimental insight into the nature of G6P substrate binding. We (in collaboration with (Dr. Yan (Jessie) Zhang at UT-Austin and Dr. Edward N. Baker from University of Aukland) have solved the crystal structure of the FGD H40A variant in complex with the substrate, G6P to a resolution of 2.9 Å. Our goal is to continue to optimize the crystallization conditions in order to get a higher resolution structure to better understand FGD interactions with G6P. Steady State Anaylsis: FGD activity was assayed by observing the decrease in the absorbance of the oxidized F420 Cofactor at 420 nm upon reduction, using a Cary-100 Spectrophotometer. The reaction kinetics was observed to follow a Michaelis-Menten model (equation 1). See table 1. k = kcat[G6P]/(Km+[G6P]) Equation 1 Table 1 Steady state kinetic parameters for wtFGD and FGD H40A Km G6P (μM) kcat (sec-1) kcat/Km (M-1sec-1) wtFGD 21.6 ± 1.5 1.4 ± 0.03 64815 FGD H40A 27.0 ± 4.8 0.0016 ± 0.0001 59.3 FNO: F420H2:NADP+oxidoreductase (Fno), is a separate F420 dependent enzyme found in sulfate reducing archaea and methanogens and thus linked to methane production. Fno catalyzes the reduction of NADP to NADPH. With this parallel project, we have: Successfully Purified Fno: The Fno gene from Archaeoglobus fulgidus was synthesized in-vitro and cloned into pET24b plasmid by Genescript. The plasmid was transformed into C41(DE3) E. coli A detailed purification procedure has been published in Protein J. Successful Production of Cofactors FO and F420: In collaboration with organic chemistry Prof. Frank Foss, a colleague at UTA, synthesis of FO, a catalytically active precursor of F420, was successfully achieved as documented by NMR spectra. There are several advantages to using the chemically synthesized FO precursor. These include: a) synthetic FO production within two weeks (as opposed to 8 weeks when grown from cells). b) the newly synthesized FO is easily purified with significantly less contaminants than the published biosynthesis protocols of FO and F420 Cofactor c) the Foss protocol produces FO on a 50 mg quantity scale, as opposed to a few milligrams from the published protocols. d) FO can be readily intercalated into Fno for kinetic studies with the enzyme. The PI, in collaboration with Dr. Foss has written a peer reviewed manuscript of this work, which has been published in Organic & Biomolecular Chemistry Journal. Initial Kinetic Studies: We have successfully employed steady state (Figure 12) and pre-steady state kinetic analysis of Fno. Furthermore, analysis of these data in terms of the initial rate of production of NADP clearly reveals biphasic kinetics, with the amplitude of the initial burst phase corresponding to 50% of FO reduction. Our data steady state data suggest that this enzyme participates in negative cooperativity kinetics. This phenomenon has not been seen previously with Fno, nor other F420 Cofactor dependent enzymes.
